I'm a librarian and instructor in information literacy and this series is great as background for students to think more deeply about what they see/hear/read. The lateral reading is very important. Students are amazed when they are required to evaluate a website and how long it actually takes to find a good one to use in research (one that is credible and less biased). I can't want to refer my students to some of these videos as background on the topics we discuss. Thank you for this series!

Thanks for the series and a lot of good advice. However, I refuse to seek out sources that disagree with my worldview. When I'm brought face to face with what 40% of this country believes, I get a tight feeling in my chest and taping a plastic bag over my head starts to look like the only reasonable course of action. I know they are out there -- I live in Texas, BELIEVE ME I know they're out there -- but please don't ask me to stare them in the face for the sake of accuracy or balance. Don't ask me to balance truth with lies, facts with assertions, tolerance with bigotry, wholesomeness with rot, love with hate, trust with fear. There's got to be another way.

Realizing that confirmation bias is a thing we all have is a huge step in viewing information in a more neutral light, because as bad as fake news is, when you yourself can't be trusted to discern it because of your preconceived notions you become part of the problem...

@8:13 I think you're wrong. As you go on to say, companies and groups focus on outrageous and emotional things to increase engagement. Engagement is often of things not of what you like but of what you hate. It's this negative push which is based on algorithms that creates a feedback loop which is a large part of the reason, I think, people on social media actually feel rather terrible. I'd also go as far as to say that at least currently the reason social media companies are so focused on trying to censor disinformation is precisely because these disinformation campaigns long term are pushing people off social media. To that end, I imagine long term social media will focus on recreating the filter bubble to block truthful things that have the same effect.

What I find interesting is that a frequent source of praise for social media is its absence of gatekeepers, yet, partly through its algorithms and partly through human behavior, it still seems to tend towards people who are socially gregarious or already in positions of great power. As I said, it seems this way to me, so if people have evidence to refute my anecdotes, I welcome it.

I'm largely basing this on having observed that, after months of posting about it on Twitter, I didn't get a whole lot of views for my webcomic, but then registering it with a couple online webcomic databases recently has led to noticeable spike in the number of people viewing my comic on my website. Obviously, I haven't been especially scientific about observing this, and anecdotes are not proof. It does seem to suggest, however, that social media may not always be an effective "leveling ground"—especially for more niche interests—since it is easier for those who are already "popular" or powerful to be heard on it.

Am I crazy for thinking this? I genuinely want to know if it's just me being angsty as someone just trying to start out as an artist in the era of social media or if this is a thing that has been observed and measured.

Once again, I notice that none of these are new problems.  Street preachers, social movement groups, rumour mongers, yellow journalism, advertisers, pamphleteers, social enclaves based on class, ethnicity, religion, or other factors that become insular,... these are all the same ideas, with similar results.  Perhaps the scope and efficiency of these tactics has improved, but my own take home message is that the digital age has improved our ability to counter these threats.  Now we aren’t beholden to trusting our church, or local newspaper, our school textbooks and their portrayal of history, a news network.  Now we can verify truth better than we ever could.  From where I sit, I suspect more people are doing just that.  That is the real difference, our empowerment, not that folks are manipulating us.  Thanks for helping to empower more people. Except for some minor updates, like maybe adjusting preferences settings and the like, these are the same techniques we should have been using even before the internet.

It all seems like anti social media

Diseases and how they Spread

Humans, we walk upon our planet as the dominant species. Yet we fail to accept that there are things that can destroy us in a blink of an eye. Disease, for as long as we have existed it has claimed more lives than any other thing. “Diseases include a large part of all causes of death worldwide”. (The Statistics Portal) These diseases can be painful and last as long as a few days, months, years and even lead to death. There are four types of diseases: Pathogenic disease, deficiency disease, hereditary disease, and physiological disease. It is important to know about each one of them in order to prevent contamination and spreading if possible.

The pathogenic diseases are those caused by a bacteria, virus, fungi, and parasites. These types of diseases are infectious, spread quickly, and among them are the most deadly. An infectious disease is transmitted from one organism to another, from person to person, animals and insects. Direct contact between infected people is one of the fasts ways of contamination. Touching hands after someone sneezes, kissing and sexual intercourse are the most common. These are the most infectious diseases of this type. HIV virus disease that effects the immune system, Herpes virus, a skin condition that causes pimple like painful sores on the skin, Dengue a flu like illness caused by a mosquito bite and can get severe without treatment. Meningitis disease that affects the brain and spinal cord, Flesh-Eating Disease a bacterium that feeds on the skin, Tuberculosis infection that attacks the lungs.
Deficiency disease is a condition caused by a lack of nutrient, specific vitamin, mineral or protein. We all live fast pace hectic lives. Always on the move. Many of us skip important meals or wind up eating unhealthy choices. This way of living in the end not only changes our physical appearance it also makes us vulnerable to diseases. When we do not eat the adequate foods, we do not get adequate nutrients either. This lack of nutrients results in a deficiency disease. Nutrients are essential to life. Our bodies need them in order to function and keep us alive. “The most widespread nutritional deficiency worldwide is iron deficiency. This is a blood disorder that causes fatigue and weakness. Over 30 percent of the world’s population is anemic” (Healthline). Vitamin A is another deficiency nutrient many people suffer especially woman. Lack of important nutrients can lead to other illness like digestive disorders, depression, constipation, heart problems just to name a few.
Hereditary diseases are becoming more common in recent years. A hereditary disease is a condition passed down from a parent to a child during the infant’s development through defective genes. Some of the most common diseases are Down syndrome, a condition that effect physical growth delays and mild intellectual disability. Usher syndrome, a condition that effects hearing and vision. Sickle cell anemia, an anemic condition that prevents adequate oxygen to circulate through the body. Muscular dystrophy, a disease that weakens the primary muscles over time. There is a lot of research to prevent and treat these types of diseases but early diagnosis of the condition is needed in order to assure the best outcome.


Physiological diseases is a malfunction of the body or organ causing other types of illness. You might want to go for a morning run and all of a sudden, you are short of breath. You start to cough your chest tightens. Common symptoms of asthma. This is an example of a physiological disease. Asthma is an illness caused by a malfunction of the lungs. Hypertension (high blood pressure) and diabetes (elevated levels of glucose in the blood) are also conditions of malfunctions of the body. These two can lead to other serious conditions that can affect the heart and other body parts. We might be the dominate species, but we have to be aware that the smallest things around us like diseases can make life not so great or even end it if we are not careful.

I think I'm genuinely addicted to the Internet... Ever since my brother passed away two years ago, I've been depressed and I've just been staying at home with my mom. I'm having a lot of trouble finishing my degree (I have just two more courses left). I've lost a lot of motivation and will-power to get up and find a job or volunteer or whatever. I just feel like it's all pointless in the end anyway. I've gotten a little fatter, as I'm always snacking at the computer. I've even let my addiction get in the way of my relationship with my fiancee. I spend so much time online, wasting 24 hours everyday, for years... And the thing that just spokes me about all this is that I'm totally self-aware of what I'm doing and it's negative affects on my personal life, relationships, and health. I know that I'm slowly letting my life go. Yet, I can't seem to shake this feeling that I always need to be on the Internet. edit no joke, even with this post, I'm constantly checking it again. I'm refreshing the page. Like, it's pathetic. And, honestly, I need to go cold turkey.
I’m binge watching YouTube at 4 am. I felt brief excitement at seeing another episode of a favorite series. Less than a minute later the episode made me feel profoundly ashamed of my life choices.
